details.description: VAT - how to register, effective date of registration, registration thresholds, de-register (cancel) or transfer a VAT registration

parts.title: Overview
parts.body:
You must register for VAT with HM Revenue & Customs (HMRC) if your business turnover is more than £77,000. You can register voluntarily if it’s below this.

When you register, you’ll be sent a VAT registration certificate in the post. This confirms:

  • your VAT number
  • your ‘effective date of registration’ - the official date you’re registered for VAT
  • when to send your first VAT Return and payment to HMRC

Your VAT responsibilities

From the effective date of registration you:

  • must charge the right amount of VAT
  • can reclaim the VAT you’ve paid on your purchases
  • must pay any VAT due to HMRC
  • must send VAT Returns
  • must keep VAT records and a VAT account

You can’t charge or show VAT on your invoices until you get a VAT number.

parts.title: How to register
parts.body:
Register for VAT

Most businesses can register online.

By doing this you’ll register for VAT and create an HMRC online account (sometimes known as a ‘Government Gateway account’). You need this to send your VAT Returns to HMRC.

Exceptions

You have to apply by post if you’re registering:

  • a business partnership
  • a business that’s part of a group or division
  • an international business

If you apply by post, you must sign up for an HMRC online account separately (select option ‘VAT submit returns’). You can only do this after HMRC sends your VAT number to you.

How long does it take?

You should get a VAT registration certificate within 30 working days, though it can take longer.

What you need to know

You need to provide details like your turnover, business activity and bank details.

Your registration date is known as your ‘effective date of registration’. You must pay HMRC the VAT due from this date.

You don’t need to authorise an agent to register you for VAT.

parts.title: When to register
parts.body:
You must register when you go over the threshold, or know that you will. The threshold is based on your estimated VAT taxable turnover - the total of everything sold that isn’t VAT exempt.

Compulsory registration

You must register for VAT if:

  • your estimated VAT taxable turnover is more than £77,000 (the ‘threshold’) in a 12 month period
  • you receive goods in the UK from the EU worth more than £77,000
  • you expect to go over the threshold in a single 30 day period

The threshold is different if you supply goods and services to the UK from abroad.

If you register late, HM Revenue & Customs (HMRC) can charge you a penalty (between 5% and 15% of the VAT you owe).

Voluntary registration

You can register voluntarily if your business turnover is below £77,000. You must pay HMRC the VAT you owe from the date they register you.

Get an exception

You can apply for a ‘registration exception’ (eg because your turnover goes over the threshold temporarily). To get an exception you must:

  • fill out the VAT registration application and the section on ‘exceptions’
  • prove your turnover is usually under £75,000

HMRC will consider your exception and write confirming if you get one. If not, they will register you for VAT.

parts.title: Purchases made before registration
parts.body:
There is a time limit for backdating claims for VAT. From your date of registration the time limit is:

  • 4 years for goods
  • 6 months for services

The claims must be for the business now registered for VAT and must relate to your business purpose.

You should reclaim them on your first VAT Return (add them to your Box 4 figure) and keep records including:

  • invoices and receipts
  • a description and purchase dates
  • information about how they relate to your business now

parts.title: Cancel registration
parts.body:
You must cancel your registration if you’re no longer eligible to be VAT registered. For example:

  • you stop trading or making VAT taxable supplies
  • you join a VAT group

VAT taxable turnover is the total of everything you sell during the year unless it is exempt from VAT.

How to cancel

Send form VAT7 to HM Revenue & Customs (HMRC) within 30 days of your reason for cancelling the registration or you may be charged a penalty.

Download form VAT7 - apply for VAT de-registration (PDF, 100KB)

What happens next

It usually takes 3 weeks for HMRC to write confirming your de-registation and the official de-registration date.

From the date of de-registration you must stop charging VAT and keep your VAT records for 6 years.

You’ll have to send a final VAT Return for the period up to and including the de-registration date.

Where to send your form

Businesses based in the UK must send the form to:

HM Revenue & Customs
VAT Registration Service
Imperial House
77 Victoria Street
Grimsby
DN31 1DB

Businesses not based in the UK must send the form to:

HM Revenue & Customs
Non Established Taxable Persons Unit (NETPU)
Ruby House
8 Ruby Place
Aberdeen
AB10 1ZP

parts.title: Transfer registration
parts.body:
To transfer a VAT registration from one business to another, send HM Revenue & Customs (HMRC) form VAT 68. For example, you take over a company and want to keep using its VAT number.

It must be signed by both the seller and buyer of the business.

Download form VAT 68, Transfer a VAT registration (PDF, 20 KB)

VAT Registration Service
HM Revenue & Customs
Imperial House
77 Victoria Street
Grimsby
DN31 1DB

What happens next

HMRC will write confirming if it has been transfered. This can take up to 3 weeks.

If necessary,

  • the seller should cancel their accountant’s access to their VAT account - eg, if they had authorised them to deal with their VAT.
  • the buyer should contact HMRC within 21 days of sending form VAT 68 if they want to keep the seller’s accountant.
  • the buyer should replace any self-billing agreements with new ones
  • the buyer may have to register for VAT from the day the business is transferred
